entries.name: Execution
entries: This weapon deals one extra die of damage when you strike a {@condition prone} creature.

baseitem.name: Breastplate
entries: This armor consists of a fitted metal chest piece worn with supple leather. Although it leaves the legs and arms relatively unprotected, this armor provides good protection for the wearer's vital organs while leaving the wearer relatively unencumbered.

baseitem.name: Chain Mail
entries: Made of interlocking metal rings, chain mail includes a layer of quilted fabric worn underneath the mail to prevent chafing and to cushion the impact of blows. The suit includes gauntlets.

baseitem.name: Chain Shirt
entries: Made of interlocking metal rings, a chain shirt is worn between layers of clothing or leather. This armor offers modest protection to the wearer's upper body and allows the sound of the rings rubbing against one another to be muffled by outer layers.

entries.name: Shield Snare
entries: Your flail attacks ignore any bonus to AC granted by shields. Additionally, as an action, you may make a single attack against a target carrying a shield or a similar defensive tool. If the attack hits, it deals normal weapon damage, and the target must make a Strength saving throw or lose hold of its shield, which lands at its feet.

entries.name: Disarming Parry
entries: When a creature attacks you with a melee weapon, you may use your reaction to attempt to catch the weapon in your glaive's hook and disarm them. Make an attack roll with your glaive. If the result of this roll equals or exceeds their attack roll, their attack misses and they must succeed on a Strength saving throw or fumble their weapon, losing hold of it temporarily. A target wielding a weapon with both hands has advantage on this roll.
A weapon disarmed in this way is automatically retrieved by its original wielder at the end of their turn, but cannot be used before then.
If you attempt to parry a weapon that cannot be disarmed, your parry attack roll is made at disadvantage. You must decide to use this feature before your opponent rolls their attack.

entries.name: Horde Sweeper
entries: Whenever you hit a creature with your greataxe, every creature adjacent to you other than the target takes damage equal to your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Arcing Slash
entries: When you attack with a greatsword, you may choose to target two creatures within your reach with a single attack. You use the same attack roll and damage roll for both targets, and deals {@damage 1d6} slashing damage instead of the weapon's normal damage die. (You still add your modifier, as normal.)
Any feature that adds damage to your weapon attacks, such as a paladin's Divine Smite, deals half damage to each target.

entries.name: Rebuff
entries: As an attack while you are wielding a halberd, you may use the haft of your weapon to rebuff up to two adjacent creatures. Make a single attack roll against one or two adjacent creatures within 5 feet of you. If the attack hits a target, you push it up to 10 feet away from you.

baseitem.name: Half Plate Armor
entries: Half plate consists of shaped metal plates that cover most of the wearer's body. It does not include leg protection beyond simple greaves that are attached with leather straps.

baseitem.name: Hide Armor
entries: This crude armor consists of thick furs and pelts. It is commonly worn by barbarian tribes, evil humanoids, and other folk who lack access to the tools and materials needed to create better armor.

entries.name: Special
entries: You have disadvantage when you use a lance to attack a target within 5 feet of you. Also, a lance requires two hands to wield when you aren't mounted.

entries.name: Charge
entries: If you move 20 or more feet straight toward a creature before hitting it with a lance attack, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d12} piercing damage and must succeed on a Strength saving throw or fall {@condition prone}.

baseitem.name: Leather Armor
entries: The breastplate and shoulder protectors of this armor are made of leather that has been stiffened by being boiled in oil. The rest of the armor is made of softer and more flexible materials.

entries.name: Lock Blades
entries: When a creature makes a melee weapon attack against you, you may use your reaction to attempt to lock blades and parry their attack. Make an attack roll with your longsword. You have advantage on this roll if you are wielding your longsword with two hands. If the result of this roll equals or exceeds their attack roll, their attack misses.
You must choose to use this feature before seeing the result of your opponent's roll.

entries.name: Slam
entries: Once per turn, when you hit a Large or smaller creature with your maul, you may choose to halve the damage and push them 15 feet away from you. You must make this choice before you roll damage.
If the target moves at least 5 feet and collides with another creature, they each take {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Momentum
entries: Once per {@i your} turn, if you miss a creature with a Maul attack, you immediately reroll the attack against another target within range, chosen randomly. This feature is non-optional.

entries.name: Cruel Blow
entries: When you score a critical hit with your morningstar, it deals one additional die of damage, and the target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} of you for one minute. A target may repeat the save at the end of its turns, ending the condition on a success.

entries.name: Special
entries: A Large or smaller creature hit by a net is {@condition restrained} until it is freed. A net has no effect on creatures that are formless, or creatures that are Huge or larger. A creature can use its action to make a DC 10 Strength check, freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success. Dealing 5 slashing damage to the net (AC 10) also frees the creature without harming it, ending the effect and destroying the net. When you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to attack with a net, you can make only one attack regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make.

baseitem.name: Padded Armor
entries: Padded armor consists of quilted layers of cloth and batting.

entries.name: Repel Charge
entries: As an action, you can set your pike against a charge. If a creature moves at least 20 feet straight toward you and attacks you, you may use your reaction to make an attack with your pike before the attacker makes its attack roll. If your attack hits, it is an automatic critical hit, and the target has disadvantage on its attack roll.

baseitem.name: Plate Armor
entries: Plate consists of shaped, interlocking metal plates to cover the entire body. A suit of plate includes gauntlets, heavy leather boots, a visored helmet, and thick layers of padding underneath the armor. Buckles and straps distribute the weight over the body.

entries.name: Parrying Dagger
entries: While wielding both a dagger and a rapier, you may use a reaction after being struck by a melee attack to roll {@dice 1d4} and add the result to your armor class until the end of the current turn, potentially causing the triggering attack to miss.
If the dagger has a flat bonus to damage rolls, you can add that bonus to the {@dice 1d4}.

baseitem.name: Ring Mail
entries: This armor is leather armor with heavy rings sewn into it. The rings help reinforce the armor against blows from swords and axes. Ring mail is inferior to chain mail, and it's usually worn only by those who can't afford better armor.

entries.name: Bloody Wound
entries: Once per turn, you may attempt to inflict a superficial but bloody wound on your opponent. In place of one attack, you can make a scimitar attack at disadvantage. If it hits, the target takes no damage, but suffers a bloody wound.

As long as the wound persists, the target takes 1d6 slashing damage at the start of each of their turns, until it uses an action to make a DC 10 Wisdom (Medicine) check or until it recieves any healing. A creature can have only one bloody wound at a time.
This feature does not work on creatures that do not bleed, such as most constructs and incorporeal undead.

baseitem.name: Shield
entries: A shield is made from wood or metal and is carried in one hand. Wielding a shield increases your Armor Class by 2. You can benefit from only one shield at a time.

entries.name: Close Quarters Combat
entries: When you successfully grapple a creature or escape a creature's grapple, you may make a single shortsword attack against that creature as a bonus action. Additionally, if a creature tries and fails to escape your grapple, you may make a single shortsword attack as a reaction against them.

baseitem.name: Spiked Armor
entries: Spiked armor is a rare type of medium armor made by dwarves. It consists of a leather coat and leggings covered with spikes that are usually made of metal.

Spiked armor can only be effectively used by barbarians following the Path of the Battlerager. Anybody else wearing spiked armor takes {@damage 1d4} piercing damage whenever they make an attack or cast a spell.

baseitem.name: Splint Armor
entries: This armor is made of narrow vertical strips of metal riveted to a backing of leather that is worn over cloth padding. Flexible chain mail protects the joints.

baseitem.name: Studded Leather Armor
entries: Made from tough but flexible leather, studded leather is reinforced with close-set rivets or spikes.

entries.name: Pin
entries: As an action, you may attempt to pin a medium creature you are grappling. Make a single trident attack; if it hits, you catch the target between the tines of the trident and bury the trident in the ground or a nearby wall. The target is {@condition restrained} until the weapon is dislodged. The target may make a Strength or Dexterity saving throw (its choice) at the end of its turns to escape.
When you have a creature pinned in this way, your trident is occupied and cannot be used as a weapon until it is dislodged.

entries.name: Usage Note
entries: Note that if you pin a creature using a trident, both your hands will be occupied- one maintaining a grapple and the other holding the trident. You can choose to end the grapple, which makes the target hard to re-pin if they escape, or you can let go of the trident, which might result in your weapon being stolen or otherwise lost when the creature escapes. You could also stand there and do nothing but hold the creature and your trident, of course.

entries.name: Sunder Armor
entries: As an action, you may make a single war pick attack {@i without proficiency} against a target wearing medium or heavy armor. On a hit, you deal normal damage with the weapon and impose a -1 penalty to the target's AC. This can stack up to three times, to a total of -3, and lasts until the armor is repaired.

At the DM's discretion, you may be able to use this ability against foes that are naturally armored with some sort of hard material, such as the plating of a metallic golem or the scales of a dragon. If you do so, the AC penalty does not stack, and maximizes at -1.

entries.name: Ringing Blow
entries: As an action, you may make a single warhammer attack. If it hits, it deals its normal damage, and the target has disadvantage on any Concentration saving throw triggered by this damage. Additionally, they have disadvantage on all Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma checks until the end of their next turn.

entries.name: Ammunition
entries: You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.
If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

entries.name: Ammunition
entries: You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack. Loading a one-handed weapon requires a free hand. The ammunition of a firearm is destroyed upon use.
If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon. A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

entries.name: Burst Fire
entries: A weapon that has the burst fire property can make a single-target attack, or it can spray a 10-foot-cube area within normal range with shots. Each creature in the area must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or take the weapon's normal damage. This action uses ten pieces of ammunition.

entries.name: Finesse
entries: When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

entries.name: Heavy
entries: Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.

entries.name: Light
entries: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

entries.name: Loading
entries: Because of the time required to load this weapon, you can fire only one piece of ammunition from it when you use an action, bonus action, or reaction to fire it, regardless of the number of attacks you can normally make.

However, for each additional attack sacrificed in this way, you deal three extra dice of damage. For example, a level 5 fighter using a heavy crossbow would make only one crossbow attack as the Attack action, but it would have a base damage of 4d10, while a level 11 fighter would deal 7d10 damage. If you {@action Ready} an attack as an action, you can treat it as having sacrificed the same number of attacks as if you had taken the Attack action.
This does not work if you negate the loading feature of crossbows in any way.

entries.name: Reach
entries: This weapon adds 5 feet to your reach when you attack with it. This property also determines your reach for opportunity attacks with a reach weapon.
However, reach weapons are also difficult to use in close quarters; you cannot use a reach weapon to attack a creature in your own space.

entries.name: Reload
entries: A limited number of shots can be made with a weapon that has the reload property. A character must then reload it using an action or a bonus action (the character's choice).

entries.name: Thrown
entries: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

entries.name: Damage Reduction
entries: If a set of armor has the damage reduction X property, you reduce every instance of bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage you take by X. Damage reduction triggers only once per instance of damage, is applied before resistance, and can never reduce damage below 0.

entries.name: Two-Handed
entries: This weapon requires two hands to use. This property is relevant only when you attack with the weapon, not when you simply hold it.

entries.name: Versatile
entries: This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property—the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

itemType.name: Artisan's Tools
entries: These special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade. Proficiency with a set of artisan's tools lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make using the tools in your craft. Each type of artisan's tools requires a separate proficiency.

itemType.name: Gaming Set
entries: If you are proficient with a gaming set, you can add your proficiency bonus to ability checks you make to play a game with that set. Each type of gaming set requires a separate proficiency.

itemType.name: Instrument
entries: If you have proficiency with a given musical instrument, you can add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make to play music with the instrument.
A bard can use a musical instrument as a spellcasting focus, substituting it for any material component that does not list a cost.
Each type of musical instrument requires a separate proficiency.

entries.name: Range
entries: A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range shown in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's maximum range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

itemType.name: Trade Good
entries: Most wealth is not in coins. It is measured in livestock, grain, land, rights to collect taxes, or rights to resources (such as a mine or a forest).

Guilds, nobles, and royalty regulate trade. Chartered companies are granted rights to conduct trade along certain routes, to send merchant ships to various ports, or to buy or sell specific goods. Guilds set prices for the goods or services that they control, and determine who may or may not offer those goods and services. Merchants commonly exchange trade goods without using currency.

entries.name: Crew
entries: A ship needs a crew of skilled hirelings to function. As per the Player's Handbook, one skilled hireling costs at least 2 gp per day. The minimum number of skilled hirelings needed to crew a ship depends on the type of vessel.

You can track the loyalty of individual crew members or the crew as a whole using the optional loyalty rules in chapter 4 of the Dungeon Master's Guide. If at least half the crew becomes disloyal during a voyage, the crew turns hostile and stages a mutiny. If the ship is berthed, disloyal crew members leave the ship and never return.

entries.name: Passengers
entries: This indicates the number of Small and Medium passengers the ship can accommodate.
Accommodations consist of shared hammocks in tight quarters. A ship outfitted with private accommodations can carry one-fifth as many passengers.
A passenger is usually expected to pay 5 sp per day for a hammock, but prices can vary from ship to ship. A small private cabin usually costs 2 gp per day.

entries.name: Cargo
entries: The maximum tonnage the ship can carry.

entries.name: Damage Threshold
entries: If a ship has a Damage Threshold, it has immunity to all damage unless it takes an amount of damage equal to or greater than its damage threshold, in which case it takes damage as normal. Any damage that fails to meet or exceed the damage threshold is considered superficial and doesn't reduce the ship's hit points.

entries.name: Ship Repair
entries: Repairs to a damaged ship can be made while the vessel is berthed. Repairing 1 hit point of damage requires 1 day and costs 20 gp for materials and labor.

itemEntry.name: Ring of Resistance
entriesTemplate: You have resistance to {{item.resist}} damage while wearing this ring. The ring is set with {{item.detail1}}.

itemEntry.name: Armor of Resistance
entriesTemplate: You have resistance to {{item.resist}} damage while you wear this armor.

itemEntry.name: Potion of Resistance
entriesTemplate: When you drink this potion, you gain resistance to {{item.resist}} damage for 1 hour.

itemEntry.name: Absorbing Tattoo
entriesTemplate: Produced by a special needle, this magic tattoo features designs that emphasize one color ({{item.detail1}}).

entriesTemplate.name: Tattoo Attunement
entries: To attune to this item, you hold the needle to your skin where you want the tattoo to appear, pressing the needle there throughout the attunement process. When the attunement is complete, the needle turns into the ink that becomes the tattoo, which appears on the skin.
If your attunement to the tattoo ends, the tattoo vanishes, and the needle reappears in your space.

entriesTemplate.name: Damage Resistance
entries: While the tattoo is on your skin, you have resistance to {{item.resist}} damage.

entriesTemplate.name: Damage Absorption
entries: When you take {{item.resist}} damage, you can use your reaction to gain immunity against that instance of the damage, and you regain a number of hit points equal to half the damage you would have taken. Once this reaction is used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

itemEntry.name: Chromatic Rose
entriesTemplate: While this rose is held, it {{item.detail1}} as a harmless visual effect.

While holding the rose by its stem, you gain resistance to {{item.resist}} damage. If you would take more than 10 {{item.resist}} damage from a single source (after applying the resistance), the rose disintegrates, and you take no damage instead.

As an action, you can blow the petals from the rose to produce a 20-foot cone of {{item.resist}}. Each creature in the cone must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking {@damage 3d10} {{item.resist}} damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Using this property destroys the rose.

entries: Proficiency with a musical instrument indicates you are familiar with the techniques used to play it. You also have knowledge of some songs commonly performed with that instrument.

entries.name: History
entries: Your expertise aids you in recalling lore related to your instrument.

entries.name: Performance
entries: Your ability to put on a good show is improved when you incorporate an instrument into your act.

entries.name: Compose a Tune
entries: As part of a long rest, you can compose a new tune and lyrics for your instrument. You might use this ability to impress a noble or spread scandalous rumors with a catchy tune.
Proficiency with a gaming set applies to one type of game, such as Three-Dragon Ante or games of chance that use dice.

entries.name: Components
entries: A gaming set has all the pieces needed to play a specific game or type of game, such as a complete deck of cards or a board and tokens.

entries.name: History
entries: Your mastery of a game includes knowledge of its history, as well as of important events it was connected to or prominent historical figures involved with it.

entries.name: Insight
entries: Playing games with someone is a good way to gain understanding of their personality, granting you a better ability to discern their lies from their truths and read their mood.

entries.name: Sleight of Hand
entries: Sleight of Hand is a useful skill for cheating at a game, as it allows you to swap pieces, palm cards, or alter a die roll. Alternatively, engrossing a target in a game by manipulating the components with dexterous movements is a great distraction for a pickpocketing attempt.

entries.caption: Gaming Set
rows: Gain insight into an opponent's personality
